input: DOCTOR: What brings you in today?\nPATIENT: Well, I guess it’s been getting worse over the past few years, especially when I walk or try to run. Sometimes my feet feel really weird, like burning or numb, and I just can't seem to keep them steady anymore. It’s kind of scary, honestly, and I don’t really know why it’s happening or what I should do about it.
output:
THINKING: The patient reports that symptoms have been worsening over the past few years, specifically when walking or running. The symptoms include abnormal sensations such as burning or numbness in the feet, as well as balance issues. These are new details provided in this conversation; the prior vignette did not include the duration, specific symptoms, or the fact that they worsen with activity.  
ANSWER: The patient reports that over the past few years, they have experienced worsening symptoms, particularly when walking or running. They feel burning or numbness in their feet and have difficulty maintaining balance.

input:
DOCTOR: What brings you in today?
PATIENT: Well, I guess it’s been getting worse over the past few years, especially when I walk or try to run. Sometimes my feet feel really weird, like burning or numb, and I just can't seem to keep them steady anymore. It’s kind of scary, honestly, and I don’t really know why it’s happening or what I should do about it.
DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about when you first started noticing these symptoms, how they have changed over time, and whether you've experienced any other related issues or health problems?
PATIENT: Uh, well, I guess I first started noticing my feet feeling weird, like a burning or tingling sensation, maybe about four years ago? At first, it wasn’t really bothering me much, but lately, it’s been worse, and I feel like I can’t really stand or walk properly anymore. Sometimes my legs feel really weak, and I get these cramps that come and go. I don’t really know if it’s connected, but I also occasionally feel numbness or tingling in my fingertips. I don’t remember having any big problems before this, and I haven’t had any other health issues I can think of. It’s just kind of been slowly creeping up on me.
output:
THINKING: The conversation adds new details about the onset and progression of the symptoms, confirming they began approximately four years ago with sensory disturbances like burning and tingling in the feet. The symptoms have worsened over time, affecting the patient’s ability to stand or walk, accompanied by leg weakness and cramps. The patient also experiences occasional numbness or tingling in the fingertips. There were no prior health issues or significant problems before these symptoms started.  
ANSWER: The patient reports that approximately four years ago, they first noticed their feet feeling weird, like burning or tingling. Over time, these symptoms worsened, leading to difficulty standing and walking properly. They also experience leg weakness, cramps, and occasional numbness or tingling in their fingertips. They have no other known health issues.

input:
DOCTOR: What brings you in today?
PATIENT: Well, I guess it’s been getting worse over the past few years, especially when I walk or try to run. Sometimes my feet feel really weird, like burning or numb, and I just can't seem to keep them steady anymore. It’s kind of scary, honestly, and I don’t really know why it’s happening or what I should do about it.
DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about when you first started noticing these symptoms, how they have changed over time, and whether you've experienced any other related issues or health problems?
PATIENT: Uh, well, I guess I first started noticing my feet feeling weird, like a burning or tingling sensation, maybe about four years ago? At first, it wasn’t really bothering me much, but lately, it’s been worse, and I feel like I can’t really stand or walk properly anymore. Sometimes my legs feel really weak, and I get these cramps that come and go. I don’t really know if it’s connected, but I also occasionally feel numbness or tingling in my fingertips. I don’t remember having any big problems before this, and I haven’t had any other health issues I can think of. It’s just kind of been slowly creeping up on me.
DOCTOR: Can you describe how these symptoms have affected your daily life and if you've noticed anything that makes them better or worse?
PATIENT: Um, it’s kind of hard to do some of the things I used to, like climbing stairs or running around with my kids. Sometimes the burning in my feet feels worse if I stand too long, and I feel pretty clumsy now. Nothing really seems to make it better, but I’ve noticed it gets a little worse when I’m tired or if I’m on my feet a lot.
output:
THINKING: The patient has provided additional details about the impact of their symptoms on daily life, such as difficulty climbing stairs and increased clumsiness, with symptoms worsening when tired or on their feet. These details reinforce the severity and functional impairment caused by their sensory symptoms. There is no new information about underlying causes or other health conditions.  
ANSWER: The patient reports that the symptoms have made it harder to do activities like climbing stairs or running with their kids, and they feel pretty clumsy now. The burning sensation in the feet worsens if they stand too long, and symptoms tend to get worse when they are tired or on their feet a lot. There are no other known health issues reported.

At first, it wasn’t really bothering me much, but lately, it’s been worse, and I feel like I can’t really stand or walk properly anymore. I don’t remember having any big problems before this, and I haven’t had any other health issues I can think of. It’s just kind of been slowly creeping up on me.
DOCTOR: Can you describe how these symptoms have affected your daily life and if you've noticed anything that makes them better or worse?
PATIENT: Um, it’s kind of hard to do some of the things I used to, like climbing stairs or running around with my kids. Sometimes the burning in my feet feels worse if I stand too long, and I feel pretty clumsy now. Nothing really seems to make it better, but I’ve noticed it gets a little worse when I’m tired or if I’m on my feet a lot.
DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about any other symptoms you’ve noticed, such as changes in sensation elsewhere, muscle weakness, or difficulties with coordination or balance?
PATIENT: Um, sometimes I feel like my hands and fingers go a bit numb or tingly, especially if I hold something for a while. And I guess I’ve been a little unsteady on my feet, like I might wobble or feel off-balance sometimes, but I’m not sure if that’s just in my head or if it’s real.
output:
THINKING: The latest conversation introduces new details confirming worse symptoms with activity and fatigue, as well as increased unsteadiness and occasional numbness or tingling in the hands and fingers. These support ongoing sensory and motor symptoms affecting the patient's daily functioning. No new underlying causes or additional health conditions are mentioned.  
ANSWER: The patient reports that the symptoms have made it harder to do activities like climbing stairs or running with their kids, and they feel pretty clumsy now. The burning sensation in the feet worsens if they stand too long, and symptoms tend to get worse when they are tired or on their feet a lot. They also experience numbness or tingling in their fingertips, especially if they hold something for a while, and sometimes feel unsteady or off-balance when walking. There are no other known health issues reported.
